unnormalised: Bangalore-based startup, "CodeNinjas," just launched their new AI-powered coding assistant, "DevBuddy," at 10 AM today. Initial reports say it can cut down debugging time by as much as 40%, which is pretty awesome for developers pulling all-nighters. The tool supports languages like Python 3.9 and Javascript ES6, and they're promising support for more soon.
normalised: Bangalore-based startup, "CodeNinjas," just launched their new A-I-powered coding assistant, "DevBuddy," at ten A-M today. Initial reports say it can cut down debugging time by as much as forty percent, which is pretty awesome for developers pulling all-nighters. The tool supports languages like Python three point nine and Javascript E-S-six, and they're promising support for more soon.

unnormalised: DevBuddy is currently available on a subscription basis, costing ₹2500/month for individual developers and ₹10000/month for teams up to 5 members. Early bird users are also getting a sweet deal of 20% off for the 1st 3 months if they sign up before 30/06/2024. They're also boasting about its integration with VS Code 1.60+, which should make life easier.
normalised: DevBuddy is currently available on a subscription basis, costing rupee two thousand five hundred per month for individual developers and rupee ten thousand per month for teams up to five members. Early bird users are also getting a sweet deal of twenty percent off for the first three months if they sign up before thirtieth June two thousand and twenty four. They're also boasting about its integration with V-S Code one point six zero plus, which should make life easier.

unnormalised: CEO Rohan Sharma mentioned that DevBuddy uses a model trained on over 5 million lines of open-source code. He also added that the beta testers saw a drop in error rate by approx. 15%. They are looking at further expanding into other tools too. Keep an eye out for updates from CodeNinjas.
normalised: C-E-O Rohan Sharma mentioned that DevBuddy uses a model trained on over five million lines of open-source code. He also added that the beta testers saw a drop in error rate by approximately fifteen percent. They are looking at further expanding into other tools too. Keep an eye out for updates from CodeNinjas.
